node.title: Is it possible to make a peridynamics ADKernel?
node.bodyText:
Dear All,
I want to modify peridynamics kernel, but writing the full jacobian for it would be a headache due to nonlocal interaction. Therefore, using an ADKernel seems like an attractive option.
The existing PD implementation inherits from the regular kernel and overrides the computeResidual() method rather than using computeQpResidual(). However, the computeResidual() in Kernel.h is virtual but it is not in ADKernel.h, and if my understanding is correct it is not meant to be overridden.
But it is better to ask before starting to write a long jacobian. So is it possible to implement a peridynamics ADKernel?

Hello
Whether for ADKernel or Kernel you want to override computeQpResidual. Overriding computeResidual is for expert users.
It should be possible to write an ADKernel for PD. I think some complexity might come from how to handle the bonds breaking but a similar treatment as for non AD might be possible
AD was added to moose after peridynamics which is why there is no AD in PD right now

Note that you can mix and match ADKernel(s) and Kernel(s), so you dont need to implement every PD kernel with AD immediately.
The only issue is material properties, which can be either AD or non AD but not both. They can be converted with this material
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/materials/MaterialADConverter.html
but derivatives are generally lost in the process

node.title: ion interaction and segregation
node.bodyText:
Dear MOOSE users,
I am trying to simulate the interaction of two different ion types and their segregation in two separate pores, whereby each pore will accommodate one ion type. Should I use the chemical reaction module for this sort of computation? I would appreciate your advice. If you can direct me to the right module or examples I can follow to set up such a simulation in MOOSE, I will be immensely grateful to you.
Thanks, and best regards,
Zahid

Hello
Is the spatial part of this process diffusion driven or advection driven?

the chemical reactions module will handle the reaction term well, and will have utilities to set up chains of reactions if needed. For two species, it should be easy enough to set up the equations manually with Reaction kernels though
@GiudGiud The spatial part of the process is diffusion-limited. Which reaction kernels do you mean? Will these reaction kernels consider the repulsion of chemical species and their segregation?
@GiudGiud can these reaction kernels assign repulsion between two positive or two negative ions?

I don't think we can do that with reaction terms?
What does repulsion look like in the equations?

@GiudGiud the repulsion force is based on the Coulomb's law.

Two positive ions will diffuse through and exert repulsion force on each other. Any suggestion on solution method in MOOSE?

@permcody do you know who may have worked on this?
@cticenhour same question, though I realize the EM module is not about ion repulsion

in any case this is a fairly simply form for the kernel, I could see a new kernel to model this.
The only difficulty is that there is not 2 individual ions here, but rather a concentration of ions in every mesh cell, so the force probably needs to be distributed in some manner

@zahidhasan83 Without seeing the full set of partial differential equations (PDEs) you are trying to solve, I am unsure what to say here. I would guess that the repulsion force would impact the electromigration term of a Nernst–Planck style equation modeling an individual particle concentration.
@mangerij do you have thoughts there?

A simple electrostatic potential solve can be done using one of our family of Diffusion objects with a Reaction object (or multiple) to form what would be required from each species to form the charge density term on the right-hand-side. To simulate a simple jump in potential due to differing bulk material properties, the ElectrostaticContactCondition object may be sufficient for your needs. The tunable parameters for the contact conductance explained in the documentation were tuned to fit electric field assisted sintering (EFAS) experimental data, so you might need to get an external reference for data to find a better fit to use it in your model. This might involve running the electrostatic solve separately, with some "dummy" inputs for your charge density term until you find conductance behavior you're happy with.
Once you have potential being solved, you can then couple it in to the N-P equation you presented above. Term (3) (the potential term) might require a custom MOOSE object (inheriting from Diffusion, similar to our other Diffusion family objects) in order to take in (from the input file, or defined in source code) the properties you have laid out in this screenshot as well as the variable representing the potential. Term (1) can be represented via the TimeDerivative object, and Term (2) seems like a fairly simple MatDiffusion or FunctionDiffusion term, depending on how the Diffusivity is defined.

node.title: Crystal Plasticity Slow Computation
node.bodyText:
Hi there,
I have been creating a dislocation density based crystal plasticity app in MOOSE. The app inherits from ComputeMultipleCrystalPlasticityStress and CrystalPlasticityStressUpdateBase. The app has been running just fine with smaller (~500 elements) simulations. As I have increased the size of my simulations to run more detailed microstructures, I have run into massive slowdowns. As an example, I ran a 36,000 element simulation on an HPC using 82 cores. It ran for 8 days, only getting to a strain of 0.00022 (0.022%) :

I need to get to a strain of at least 1%, and I would also like to increase the resolution of my microstructure even further (to ~300k elements). However, the speed of my app right now is far too slow to come close to these goals. Looking into other discussion posts about a slow computation time for a crystal plasticity simulation, I see that a simulation of this size should be much faster:

I see you are running with about 20k elements, for instance with 24 cpus, I would expect that simulation to take about 1 hour for each 1% strain load #26598

I have profiled my code, and it revealed that most of the runtime was being spent calculating the Jacobian and the residual. A picture of the profile is found here:

Much of the runtime is spent in calculateConstitutiveSlipDerivative , and specifically pow within that function. Here is a snippet of that function:
void
CrystalPlasticityDDStressUpdate::calculateConstitutiveSlipDerivative(std::vector<Real> & dslip_dtau)
{
  Real effective_stress;
  Real delF0 = (_enthalphy_const * _g * 1.0e6) * (std::pow(_burg_mag, 3.0)) * 1.0e-9;
  // Boltzmann constant
  Real B_k = 1.3806503e-23;
  for (const auto i : make_range(_number_slip_systems))
  {
    effective_stress = _tau[_qp][i] - _backstress[_qp][i];
    if (std::abs(effective_stress) <= _s_a[_qp][i])
      dslip_dtau[i] = 0.0;
    else if (MooseUtils::absoluteFuzzyEqual(_tau[_qp][i], 0.0))
      dslip_dtau[i] = 0.0;
    else
    {
      dslip_dtau[i] =
          _slip_rate_reference *
          std::exp((-delF0 / B_k / _temperature) *
                   std::pow(1.0 - std::pow((std::abs(effective_stress) - _s_a[_qp][i]) / _s_t,
                   _p),
                            _q)) *
          (delF0 / B_k / _temperature) * _q *
          std::pow(1.0 - std::pow((std::abs(effective_stress) - _s_a[_qp][i]) / _s_t, _p),
                   _q - 1.0) *
          _p * std::pow((std::abs(effective_stress) - _s_a[_qp][i]) / _s_t, _p - 1.0) / _s_t *
          sgn(effective_stress);
    }
    
  }
}

I do not see any obvious points in this function that would be causing major slowdowns. I have tried replacing the pow function with a faster rough approximation, but that did not help.
I believe a next step for me might be to improve the preconditioning? But I am not sure where to start with that. What type of preconditioning might give me better results for large ( > 30k elements) simulations? How would that implementation look for a CP app like this? Otherwise, would hardcoding the Jacobian improve my results? I have read that the Jacobian is calculated as part of ComputeMultipleCrystalPlasticityStress, but would hardcoding it myself improve the results? Where and how would I implement that in my app?
Here is an example of an input file I have been using:

Hello
is std::pow( used with an integer exponent by any chance?
No, they aren't integers. _p is ~0.35 and _q is ~1.3. So the exponents used in calculateConstitutiveSlipDerivative are 0.35, 1.3, -0.65, and 0.3 (or in that range. p and q can change by about +- 0.1)

ok. We have an optimized pow() for integer exponents that's why I asked
for preconditioning,
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type'
  petsc_options_value = ' lu'

solves in very few iterations but could be slower still, especially for larger simulations

Hi, @GiudGiud , thank you for the suggestion. It looks like that petsc preconditioner helped improve the runtime by about 30%. However, the runtime for simulations with over 30,000 elements is still far too long to finish in a reasonable amount of time. Would changing the MOOSE preconditioner help in any way? What would changing that look like? Also, would hard coding the Jacobian yield any other improvements?

Also, would hard coding the Jacobian yield any other improvements?

This should be 30% faster than AD if you are up for the task. It may be even fasters with tensor computations.

Would changing the MOOSE preconditioner help in any way?

Yes it can. However at 30k elements we don't expect any scaling issues. LU might already be one of the fastest options

Thanks, I will try to hand code the Jacobian then. I am a little confused where I need to implement this. Where is it that computeQpJacobian() needs to be overridden? This is something that belongs to a kernel, and not a material right? If I am using the SolidMechanics/Quasistatic master action:
[Physics/SolidMechanics/QuasiStatic/all]
  strain = FINITE
  add_variables = true
  generate_output = stress_yy
[]

how would I know what kernel to change? Thanks again for your help.

If you use Physics/SolidMechanics/QuasiStatic/all then I dont think you need to implement anything
use_automatic_differentiation in this action defaults to false
Where do I override computeQpJacobian() ?
in kernels

@GiudGiud , I think I may have misunderstood what you said here initially:

If you use Physics/SolidMechanics/QuasiStatic/all then I dont think you need to implement anything use_automatic_differentiation in this action defaults to false

Were you saying that since the solid mechanics master action doesn’t use AD by default, that I won't gain anything from trying to hand code my Jacobian?
On another note, @sapitts , I see that you have assisted with Crystal Plasticity questions in the past. Do you have any input as to why I might be having such bad scaling issues?
If it does not use AD then it does benefit from implementing the Jacobian terms manually

node.title: Query Regarding Array Bound Checks and Error Handling in MOOSE
node.bodyText:
Hi Moose Team,
I am a new MOOSE user and currently learning to use the software.
Before switching to MOOSE, I was working with Abaqus where I often used Fortran subroutines (like UMAT, UEXTERNALDB, UEL, etc.) to implement programmable features.
In Fortran subroutine, I would define arrays as follows:
real(8) :: slip_dir(num_slip_sys)
real(8) :: slip_nor(num_slip_sys)
There, If I accidentally accessed an array element beyond its defined range, the subroutine would either fail to compile or throw a segmentation fault during execution, making it easy to identify the issue and correct it.
In MOOSE, the common practice for defining arrays is:
std::vector<Real> slip_dir(_num_slip_sys); 
std::vector<Real> slip_nor(_num_slip_sys);
However, here,  if I mistakenly access an out-of-bounds index in MOOSE, I don’t get a compile-time or segmentation fault error. Instead, I typically encounter issues like poor convergence, floating-point exceptions, or other runtime errors, but not a clear segmentation fault pointing to the mistake.
My question is: Are there any ways to define arrays, or any specific compiler settings, that would catch out-of-bounds array access during compilation or execution, resulting in a more informative error (like a segmentation fault)?
Your guidance on this would be greatly appreciated.
Thank you for your support!

Hello
If you compile in debug mode (set the environment variable METHOD=dbg ) I have observed it will complain when you access out of bounds. I'm not sure how what compiler option turned that on.
An alternative is to add mooseAssert in your code to check that you do not access out of bound by comparing the index and the size
The assert is only compiled in devel and debug mode so it does not affect the opt mode performance
This won't catch anything at compilation btw. Only execution
This won't catch anything at compilation btw. Only execution

Hi  Giudicelli,
Thankyou for your reply.
Can you give an example on how to add mooseAssert for this case. I looked up in Moose Source files but didn't found any relevant case.

For example
mooseAssert(index<vector.size(), "Accessing out of bounds");

if the condition in the first part of the call is false, then the second argument, a string, is output as an error message
You can use this before indexing into the vector with vector[index]

Thankyou  Giudicelli,
for your help

node.title: Different Outputs and Pre-SMO Residual in Old and New MOOSE Application
node.bodyText:
Hi Moose Team,
I am new to MOOSE and currently in the process of learning how to use it.
I am working with a MOOSE-based application, Rhocp (https://github.com/apatra6/rhocp). When I run MOOSE input files using this Rhocp application, the command line output looks like this:
Time Step 121, time = 7.03415, dt = 0.1
Pre-SMO residual: 3.60514e-05
  Applying predictor with scale factor = 1
�[32m Solve Converged!�[39m
  Finished Solving                                                                       [�[33m  6.56 s�[39m] [�[33m  143 MB�[39m]

Time Step 122, time = 7.13415, dt = 0.1
Pre-SMO residual: 3.6051e-05
  Applying predictor with scale factor = 1
�[32m Solve Converged!�[39m
  Finished Solving                    
Since this Rhocp application uses an older MOOSE standard, I created a new Rhocp application using ~/projects/moose/scripts/stork.sh Rhocp and copied the necessary files (materials, auxkernels, userobjects, etc.) from the original version.
However, when I run the same input file using this new Rhocp-opt application, the command line output is different:
Time Step 11, time = 0.00321504, dt = 0.000619174
  Applying predictor with scale factor = 1
�[32m Solve Converged!�[39m

Time Step 12, time = 0.00395805, dt = 0.000743008
  Applying predictor with scale factor = 1
�[32m Solve Converged!�[39m

Time Step 13, time = 0.00484966, dt = 0.00089161
  Applying predictor with scale factor = 1
�[32m Solve Converged!�[39m

Time Step 14, time = 0.00591959, dt = 0.00106993
  Applying predictor with scale factor = 1
�[32m Solve Converged!�[39m
I have the following questions:


Why am I seeing different command line outputs when using the older Rhocp version from this repository compared to the new Rhocp version created using stork.sh, even though I copied the same materials, auxkernels, and other files?


What is the "Pre-SMO residual" displayed in the older version's output? How can I enable or use this feature in the new Rhocp application I created?


I have tried changing the following line in RhocpApp.C in the base folder
  InputParameters params = MooseApp::validParams();
  params.set<bool>("use_legacy_material_output") = false;
  params.set<bool>("use_legacy_initial_residual_evaluation_behavior") = true; // from false
still I am getting the same command line output with this new RhoCp based app.
Further I have noticed that for some problems the convergence with old rhocp-opt is better than new rhocp-opt. I think may be reason is this Pre-SMO residual
Thank you for your help!

Hello
First the default output of residuals might have changed. You will want to turn on more output of residuals in the Outputs block. See the CommonOutputAction for the list of parameters
The pre-SMO residual was an early residual evaluation that was not always necessary. Selecting the legacy behavior should re-establish that residual evaluation.
You can use Debug/show_execution_order=ALWAYS to see this initial residual evaluation happen.
Guillaume
Thankyou Giudicelli for your help

node.title: Help regarding Meaning of Usage of Scaling while defining the displacement variables in MOOSE SolidMechanics Physics type problem
node.bodyText:
Hi Moose Team,
I am a new Moose user and currently learning to use Moose.
I have a doubt regarding defination of variables in the Moose input file.
Ref : https://github.com/apatra6/rhocp/blob/main/examples/tantalum/strain_rate_effect/1e-4ps/bcc_pxtal.i
[Variables]
  [./disp_x]
    order = FIRST
    family = LAGRANGE
    scaling = 1e-4
  [../]
  [./disp_y]
    order = FIRST
    family = LAGRANGE
    scaling = 1e-4
  [../]
  [./disp_z]
    order = FIRST
    family = LAGRANGE
    scaling = 1e-4
  [../]
[]


I am unable to understand what is the function of scaling parameter while defining the variables for FE problem.
I have referred the MOOSE documentation and source files still didn't understood the purpose of scaling parameter in the defination of variables.
And How do we decide ideal value of scaling parameter.
Kindly help me understanding this concept.

Hello
Scaling is used as a simple preconditioning of the equations. When there are multiple equations, we weight the residuals of the equation for each variable by this scaling factor to make the convergence criterion more fair and/or help with matrix conditioning
This page on porous flow has an explanation
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/porous_flow/convergence.html#46b5c8c6-401d-44a8-80b8-1ae589dcd695

And How do we decide ideal value of scaling parameter.

Experimentally most of the time. You look at the residuals and see if they are orders of magnitude apart, maybe it's worth bringiing them closer together.

Hi Guillaume,
Thank you for your response.
From what I understand, the scaling parameter is particularly useful when solving multiphysics problems in MOOSE. Would it also be beneficial when dealing with single-physics problems, such as mechanics, in MOOSE?
Thank you.

It would because the displacements (the equation for each component) might have very different residuals still. For example a traction test might have much larger residual in the direction of the traction
Thankyou  Guillaume, for your help

node.title: Not-linear interface kernel/ BC
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
Hi, I am trying to set up an interface between two blocks A and B that looks like flux = h(nonlinear var in A, nonlinear var in B).
The closest MOOSE objects I have seen are the InterfaceReaction and InterfaceDiffusion kernels, though as far as I can tell these do not allow arbitrary functions of the nonlinear variables on either side of the interface.
In a previous question I have seen test/src/materials/JumpInterfaceMaterial.C mentioned and have taken a look at it. Would I have to implement something similar to this? Or is there a MOOSE object I am missing? Any guidance here would be appreciated.

Hello
InterfaceReaction and InterfaceDiffusion do not allow for an arbitrary function indeed, but they do allow for the dependence on variables on either side of the interface and are a good example to start from to create your own interface kernel that can handle an arbitrary h function.
Interface kernels are designed to work on interfaces between two subdomains, with a conformal mesh at the interface, and with dependencies on variables defined on one or the other side of the interface
Guillaume
